{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2015}} {|{{Infobox ship begin |infobox caption=}} <!-- commercial vessels --><!----> {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=El Faro ship.jpg |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country= |Ship name=''Puerto Rico'' (1975–1991){{br}}''Northern Lights'' (1991–2006){{br}}''El Faro'' (2006–2015)<ref name="abs" /> |Ship flag= |Ship owner=[[TOTE Maritime]] |Ship operator=[[Tote Maritime|Sea Star Line]] |Ship registry=[[San Juan, Puerto Rico]], {{flag|United States}}<ref name="abs" /> |Ship route=[[Jacksonville, Florida]] to San Juan, Puerto Rico |Ship ordered=1973 |Ship builder=[[Sun Shipbuilding & Drydock Co.]]<ref name="abs" /> |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number=670<ref name="seaweb">{{csr|register=SEAWEB|id=7395351|shipname=El Faro|accessdate=November 17, 2015}}</ref> |Ship laid down=April 11, 1974<ref name="seaweb" /> |Ship launched=November 1, 1974<ref name="seaweb" /> |Ship completed=January 16, 1975<ref name="seaweb" /> |Ship christened= |Ship maiden voyage= |Ship identification=* [[Maritime call sign|Call sign]]: WFJK * {{IMO Number|7395351}} * {{MMSI Number|368208000}} |Ship fate=Sank in [[Hurricane Joaquin]] on October 1, 2015<ref name=NYT151005/> |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption=<ref name="abs">{{csr|register=ABS|id=7500285|shipname=El Faro|accessdate=October 4, 2015}}</ref> |Ship type=[[Roll-on/roll-off]] [[cargo ship]] |Ship tonnage={{GT|31,515}}{{br}}{{NetT|21,473}}{{br}}{{DWT|14,971}} |Ship displacement= |Ship length={{convert|241|m|ft|abbr=on}} (after lengthening) |Ship beam={{Convert|28.6|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draught= |Ship draft={{convert|12.8|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship deck clearance= |Ship ramps= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=Single shaft, double reduction compound steam turbine (11,190{{nbsp}}kW) |Ship speed={{convert|22|kn}} |Ship capacity= |Ship crew=33 personnel (28 [[Americans]] and 5 [[Poles]]) on final voyage |Ship notes= }} |} '''SS ''El Faro''''' was a [[United States]]-[[Flag state|flagged]], combination [[roll-on/roll-off]] and [[lift-on/lift-off]] [[cargo ship]] crewed by [[United States Merchant Marine|U.S. merchant mariners]]. Built in 1975 by [[Sun Shipbuilding & Drydock Co.]] as '''''Puerto Rico''''', the vessel was renamed '''''Northern Lights''''' in 1991, and finally, ''El Faro'' in 2006. She was lost at sea with all hands on October 1, 2015, after losing propulsion near the [[eyewall]] of [[Hurricane Joaquin]].
''El Faro'' departed [[Jacksonville, Florida]], bound for Puerto Rico at 8:10 pm EST on September 29, 2015, when then-Tropical Storm Joaquin was several hundred miles to the east. Two days later, after Joaquin had become a [[SSHS#Category 3|Category 3 hurricane]], the vessel likely encountered [[Swell (ocean)|swells]] of {{convert|20|to|40|ft|m|0|abbr=on}} and winds over {{convert|80|kn|abbr=on}} as it sailed near the storm's [[Eye (cyclone)|eye]]. Around 7:30 a.m. on October 1, the ship had taken on water and was [[Angle of list|listing]] 15 degrees. The last report from the [[Sea captain|captain]], however, indicated that the crew had contained the flooding. Shortly thereafter, ''El Faro'' ceased all communications with shore.<ref name=":Vanity">{{cite news |quote=A recording salvaged from three miles deep tells the story of the doomed ''El Faro'', a cargo ship engulfed by a hurricane. |first1=William |last1=Langewiesche |date=April 2018|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2018/04/inside-el-faro-the-worst-us-maritime-disaster-in-decades |work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] |title="The Clock is Ticking" Inside El Faro: The Worst U.S. Maritime Disaster in Decades |accessdate=April 13, 2018}}</ref>
On October 2, the 40-year-old ship was declared missing, and an extensive search operation was launched by the [[United States Coast Guard]], with help from the [[United States Air Force|Air Force]], [[Air National Guard]], and [[United States Navy|Navy]]. They recovered debris and a damaged [[Lifeboat (shipboard)|lifeboat]], and spotted (but could not recover) an unidentifiable body. ''El Faro'' was declared sunk on October 5. The search was called off at sunset on October 7, by which time more than {{convert|183,000|nmi2|abbr=on}} had been covered by aircraft and ships. The Navy sent the [[USNS Apache (T-ATF-172)|USNS ''Apache'']] to conduct an underwater search for ''El Faro'' on October 19, 2015.<ref name="CBS Corporation">{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[CBS News]]|publisher=[[CBS Corporation]]|date=October 19, 2015|accessdate=October 19, 2015|title=U.S. Navy launches salvage operation for sunken cargo ship|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/u-s-navy-joins-search-for-cargo-ship-lost-near-bahamas-during-hurricane-joaquin/|location=Miami, Florida}}</ref> The ''Apache'' identified a vessel on October 31 "consistent with [the ''El Faro''] cargo ship...in an upright position and in one piece."<ref name="Steve Almasy">{{cite news|author=Steve Almasy|work=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|date=October 31, 2015|accessdate=October 31, 2015|title=U.S. Navy finds wreckage believed to be missing cargo ship El Faro|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/10/31/us/el-faro-search/index.html}}</ref> The next day, November 1, the Navy announced a submersible had returned images that identified the wreck as the ''El Faro''.<ref>Ashley Halsey III, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trafficandcommuting/navy-finds-ship-that-sank-near-bahamas-in-hurricane-joaquin/2015/11/02/0e824e3c-8195-11e5-9afb-0c971f713d0c_story.html "Navy finds ship that sank near Bahamas in Hurricane Joaquin"], ''[[Washington Post]]'', November 2, 2015.</ref>
==Construction and earlier career== ''El Faro'' was built by the [[Sun Shipbuilding|Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Corporation]] in [[Chester, Pennsylvania]], in 1975 as ''Puerto Rico''.<ref name="abs"/> As operated by the Navieras de Puerto Rico Steamship Company, the ''Puerto Rico'' hauled cargo to and from the U.S. East Coast for 15 years. In 1991, it was purchased by [[Saltchuk]] Resources, the parent company of [[TOTE Maritime]], and renamed ''Northern Lights''. Two years later, it was lengthened by {{convert|90|ft|m}} at Alabama Shipyard, Inc.<ref name="abs"/> Under Saltchuk, it frequently sailed between [[Tacoma, Washington]], and [[Anchorage, Alaska]].<ref name="SeattleTimes1011">{{cite news|author=Coral Garnick|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|publisher=[[The Seattle Times Company]]|date=October 11, 2015|accessdate=October 13, 2015|title=El Faro cargo ship was expected to make Tacoma-Alaska run this winter|url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/news/business/article38779368.html|location=Seattle, Washington}}</ref>
In February 2003, just before the United States-led [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invasion of Iraq]], the vessel was chartered by the United States' [[Military Sealift Command]] as part of [[Operation Enduring Freedom|Operation Iraqi Freedom]]; the vessel ferried [[United States Marine Corps|Marines]] and supplies from [[San Diego, California]], to [[Kuwait]].<ref name="SeattleTimes1011"/><ref name="NDTA">{{cite journal|journal=Defense Transportation Journal|publisher=National Defense Transportation Association|date=February 2006|accessdate=October 13, 2015|title=SS Northern Lights: A Lesson in Commitment|url=http://www.ndtahq.com/images/pdf/northernlights.pdf|format=PDF|pages=9–11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111103185926/http://www.ndtahq.com/images/pdf/NorthernLights.pdf|archive-date=November 3, 2011|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> On March 19, while in the [[Persian Gulf]], the vessel came under fire from missiles. The explosions rocked the ship, but caused no damage or injuries. Through October 2005, near the end of ''Northern Lights''{{'}} chartered service, the vessel made 25 voyages and 49 port calls. Collectively, 12,200 pieces of military equipment—weighing {{convert|81,000|ST|tonne}} in all—were transported by the ship. Robert Magee, then president of TOTE, and the crew of ''Northern Lights'' were praised by [[United States Air Force]] [[General (United States)|general]] [[Norton A. Schwartz]]: "You and your team of professionals showcased the US flag industry at its best."<ref name="NDTA"/> Following completion of its military services in 2006, the ship was transferred by TOTE to its subsidiary company Sea Star Lines and renamed ''El Faro''. The vessel returned to its original route and served as a "lifeline" between the United States and [[Puerto Rico]].<ref name="SeattleTimes1011"/>
When it sank on October 1, 2015, the Merchant Vessel ''El Faro'' was scheduled to return to Tacoma to relieve another vessel.<ref name="SeattleTimes1011"/>
==Sinking== {{see also|Hurricane Joaquin}}
===Final voyage=== [[Image:El Faro life ring.JPG|thumb|left|Life ring recovered on October 3]] On September 29, 2015, at 8:10 p.m., ''El Faro'' left [[Jacksonville, Florida]] for [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]], carrying a cargo of 391 shipping containers, about 294 trailers and cars, and a crew of 33 people—28 Americans and 5 [[Poles]].<ref name=NYT151005/> The ship's master, Captain Michael Davidson, charted a course that, according to TOTE Maritime, took the vessel a reasonably safe distance away from the hurricane.<ref name="CNNOct9">{{cite news|author1=Steve Almasy |author2=Yasmin Khorram |lastauthoramp=yes |work=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|date=October 9, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=El Faro had leaks, holes, other structural issues, former crew members say|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/10/08/us/el-faro-missing-ship/}}</ref> At the time of departure, Hurricane Joaquin was still a tropical storm, but meteorologists at the [[National Hurricane Center]] forecast that it would likely become a [[hurricane]] by the morning of October 1, on a southwest trajectory toward the Bahamas.<ref>{{cite report|author=Daniel P. Brown|date=September 30, 2015|title=Tropical Storm Joaquin Discussion Number 9|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 7, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2015/al11/al112015.discus.008.shtml|location=Miami, Florida}}</ref> The vessel's charted course took it within {{convert|175|nmi|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} of the storm, where seas in excess of {{convert|10|ft|m|0|abbr=on}} were likely.<ref name="WUnderground"/> TOTE could have vetoed the captain's sail plan into the area of a predicted hurricane, but chose not to and opted for the ship to continue. The company said there was no incentive for Davidson to maintain the ship's schedule, but that the schedule also appeared to be a safe one.<ref>{{Cite web|title= TOTE: Company could've vetoed El Faro's captain|url= http://www.firstcoastnews.com/story/news/local/2015/10/05/tote-acknowledges-captain-could-have-been-overruled/73427310|author= Garrett Pelican|publisher= [[WTLV]]|date= October 6, 2015}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> At least one of the deck officers, second mate Danielle Randolph, voiced concern prior to sailing and wrote in an email to friends and family, "there is a hurricane out here and we are heading straight into it."<ref>Michael E. Miller, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/10/05/daughters-last-message-from-el-faro-there-is-a-hurricane-out-here-and-we-are-heading-straight-into-it/ "Last message from El Faro: ‘There is a hurricane out here and we are heading straight into it’"], ''Washington Post'', October 5, 2015.</ref>
The vessel had "passed its annual Coast Guard inspection in March and another survey in June",<ref>{{Cite web|title = Doomed Cargo Ship El Faro Needed Work on Boilers: NTSB|url = http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/doomed-cargo-ship-el-faro-was-due-have-boilers-serviced-n447856?cid=sm_twitter_feed_world|website = NBC News|accessdate = November 7, 2015}}</ref> and had also successfully completed the [[American Bureau of Shipping|American Bureau of Shipping (ABS)]] class and statutory surveys in February 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|title = NTSB Issues Update on Investigation Into Sinking of Cargo Ship EL FARO|url = http://www.ntsb.gov/news/press-releases/Pages/PR20151020.aspx|website = www.ntsb.gov|accessdate = November 7, 2015}}</ref> The [[National Transportation Safety Board|NTSB]] confirmed on October 20, 2015, that El Faro had successfully completed the American Bureau of Shipping (ABS) class and statutory surveys on February 13, 2015. They also found that safety drills were conducted on a weekly basis and that the ship met stability criteria when it left Jacksonville.<ref>{{Cite web|title = El Faro captain reported hull breach, NTSB says - CNN.com|url = http://www.cnn.com/2015/10/20/us/el-faro-ntsb-investigation/index.html|website = CNN|accessdate = November 7, 2015}}</ref>
Former crew members of ''El Faro'' expressed surprise and shock that the vessel set sail with a major storm in its course. They said the vessel was "a rust bucket" that "[was not] supposed to be on the water." They also said that ''El Faro'' suffered from drainage issues and that leaking was common in the Galley (Kitchen) Compartment. They said that the ship was covered in rust and its decks filled with holes as recently as August.<ref name="CNNOct9"/>
===Hurricane Joaquin=== [[Image:Joaquin 2015-10-01 1145z.png|thumb|right|Satellite image at 11:45 UTC (7:45 a.m. EDT) on October 1 depicting the approximate final position of the ''El Faro'' in relation to Hurricane Joaquin]] Throughout September 30 into the morning of October 1, Joaquin continued to track southwest.<ref name="WUnderground"/> 10 hours after departing, ''El Faro'' was steaming at full speed and deviating from its charted course. According to Klaus Luhta of the [[International Organization of Masters, Mates & Pilots]], Davidson continued to head directly into the storm.<ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|work=[[Fox News Channel|Fox News]]|publisher=[[Fox Entertainment Group]]|date=October 9, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=Doomed cargo ship reportedly left normal course, sailed into the track of Hurricane Joaquin|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2015/10/09/doomed-cargo-ship-reportedly-left-normal-course-sailed-into-track-hurricane/}}</ref> Joaquin became a hurricane by 8:00 a.m. on September 30, then [[rapid intensification|rapidly intensified]].<ref name="WUnderground"/><ref>{{cite report|author=Jack L. Beven|date=September 30, 2015|title=Hurricane Joaquin Public Advisory Number 10-A|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 7, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2015/al11/al112015.public_a.010.shtml|location=Miami, Florida|type=Advisory}}</ref> By 11:00 pm, the storm had reached [[SSHS#Category 3|Category 3 intensity]] with [[maximum sustained wind]]s of {{convert|100|kn|abbr=on|sigfig=3}}.<ref>{{cite report|author1=Daniel P. Brown |author2=Stacy R. Stewart |lastauthoramp=yes |date=September 30, 2015|title=Hurricane Joaquin Public Advisory Number 13|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 10, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2015/al11/al112015.public.013.shtml|location=Miami, Florida|type=Advisory}}</ref> Around 7:30 a.m. on October 1, less than 30 hours after the ship had sailed from Jacksonville, the [[United States Coast Guard]] received a satellite notification that the vessel had lost propulsion, taken on water—though flooding was contained at the time of the message—and had a 15-degree [[Angle of list|list]].<ref name="USCGOct3">{{cite web|publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]]|date=October 3, 2015|accessdate=October 3, 2015|title=Update 2: Coast Guard Searching for Container Ship Caught in Hurricane Joaquin|url=http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2607310/|location=Miami, Florida|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005144311/http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2607310/|archive-date=October 5, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
The Coast Guard also received a single ping from the ship's [[Emergency Position Indicating Radio Beacon]].<ref name="Press-Herald">{{cite news|author1=Dennis Hoey |author2=Beth Quimby |lastauthoramp=yes |newspaper=[[Portland Press Herald]]|publisher=[[MaineToday Media]]|date=October 5, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=Coast Guard finds debris field of missing cargo ship with Mainers on board|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2015/10/04/search-back-on-for-lost-cargo-ship-with-mainers-on-board/}}</ref> Subsequent attempts by the Coast Guard to open communications with ''El Faro'' were unsuccessful.<ref name="USCG1" />
Marine Traffic's last reported position of ''El Faro'' was {{coord|24.2747|-74.94522|name=El Faro's position at 4:01 a.m. on October 1}} at 4:01 a.m., heading south-southeast at {{convert|19|kn|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marinetraffic.com/ais/details/ships/shipid:454389/mmsi:368208000/imo:7395351/vessel:EL_FARO|title=El Faro|website=Marinetraffic.com|date=October 1, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015}}</ref> According to a different marine positioning database, relayed by [[Reuters]], the final relayed position of ''El Faro'' was {{coord|23.52|-74.02|name=El Faro's position at 7:56 a.m. on October 1}} at 7:56 a.m.,<ref name="WUnderground"/> about {{convert|35|nmi|abbr=on}} northeast of [[Crooked Island, Bahamas|Crooked Island]].<ref name="NYTOct7"/> This placed the vessel within the [[Eye (cyclone)#Eyewall|eyewall]] of Hurricane Joaquin, situated near {{coord|23.2|-73.7|name=Location of Hurricane Joaquin at 8:00 a.m. on October 1}} at 8:00 a.m., where winds in excess of {{convert|80|kn|abbr=on}} and waves of {{convert|20|to|30|ft|m|0|abbr=on}} likely battered the ship.<ref name="WUnderground">{{cite web|author=Jeff Masters|publisher=[[Weather Underground (weather service)|Weather Underground]]|date=October 7, 2015|accessdate=October 7, 2015|title=Last Known Position of the Missing Ship El Faro: the Eyewall of Category 3 Joaquin|url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=3149}}</ref><ref>{{cite report|author=Jack L. Beven|date=October 1, 2015|title=Hurricane Joaquin Public Advisory Number 10-A|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 10, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2015/al11/al112015.public_a.014.shtml|location=Miami, Florida|type=Advisory}}</ref>
==== Voyage Data Recorder audio ==== {{Overly detailed|date=September 2018}} On 13 December 2016, the NTSB released a 500-page transcript of the conversations that occurred on the bridge in the ship's final 26 hours, as recorded by the Vessel's Voyage Data Recorder (VDR) and its six microphones.
The transcript described a quickly deteriorating situation.
At 5:43 am, the captain takes a phone call indicating suspected flooding in the no. 3 cargo hold and sends the chief mate to investigate. The crew then begin taking measures to try to assess and control the flooding.<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|415–416}}
At 6:13 am, the ship loses its steam propulsion plant.<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|439}}
At 6:54 am, the captain takes a phone call describing the situation onboard:
* "It’s miserable right now. We got all the uhh—all the wind on the starboard side here. Now a scuttle was left open or popped open or whatever so we got some flooding down in three hold—a significant amount. Umm, everybody’s safe right now, we’re not gonna abandon ship—we’re gonna stay with the ship. We are in dire straits right now. Okay, I’m gonna call the office and tell ’em [expletives]. Okay? Umm there’s no need to ring the general alarm yet—we’re not abandoning ship. The engineers are trying to get the plant back. So we’re working on it—okay?"<ref name=vdr>{{Cite web|url=https://dms.ntsb.gov/public/58000-58499/58116/606566.pdf|title=Group Chairman's Factual Report of Investigation: Attachment 1 to Addendum — Voyage Data Recorder — Audio Transcript (Revised version, including changes from the Addendum and Errata), ''SS El Faro'' DCA16MM001|author=Sean Payne|date=August 8, 2017|website=National Transportation Safety Board|publisher=Office of Research and Engineering, Vehicle Recorder Division|access-date=28 August 2017}}</ref>{{rp|467}}
At 7:06 am, the captain makes a phone call. He says:
* "I have a marine emergency and I would like to speak with a QI. We had a hull breach- a scuttle [hatch] blew open during the storm. We have water down in three hold. We have a heavy list. We've lost the main propulsion unit. The engineers can not get it goin'. Can I speak with a QI please?"<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|475}} * "We have uhh secured the source of water coming in to the vessel. uh, A scuttle was blown open... it's since been closed. However, uh, three hold's got a considerable amount of water in it. Uh, we have a very, very healthy port list. The engineers cannot get lube oil pressure on the plant, therefore we've got no main engine, and let me give you um a latitude and longitude. I just wanted to give you a heads up before I push that- push that button."<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|476}} * "The crew is safe. Right now we're trying to save the ship now, but uh all available hands. We are forty-eight miles east of San Salvador. We are taking every measure to take the list off. By that I mean pump out that- pump out that hold the best we can but we are not gaining ground at this time."<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|477}} * "Right now it's a little hard to tell because all the wind is... on that side too so we got a good wind heel goin'. But it's not getting any better."<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|478}} * "[We're] gonna stay with the ship... no one's panicking, everybody's been made aware... Our safest bet is to stay with the ship during this particular time. The weather is ferocious out here and we're gonna stay with the ship... swell is out the northeast, a solid ten to twelve feet (over) spray, high winds, very poor visibility..."<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|478}}
At 7:10 am, the captain tells someone on the phone that they have a 10- to 15-degree list, "but a lot of that's with the wind heel."<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|480}} He lets the person know he will be making a distress call to the USCG, and then directs the second mate to activate the [[Ship Security Alert System|SSAS]] button/[[GMDSS]] alarm, and directs her to wake everybody up.<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|481–482}}
At 7:15 am, the chief mate returns to the bridge:
* Chief mate: "I think that the water level's rising, Captain." * Captain: "(okay). Do you know where it's comin' from?" * Chief Mate: "(at) first the Chief said something hit the fire main. Got it ruptured. Hard." * Captain: "Um, there's no way to secure that?" * Chief Mate: "We don't know if they still have any pressure on the fire main or not. Don't know where's sea – between the sea suction and the hull or what uh but anything I say is a guess."<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|483}}
At 7:17 am, the chief engineer informs the chief mate and the captain over the sound-powered phone that the bilge alarm is going off in "two alpha."<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|485}} The captain asks the chief if he can pump out all of the cargo holds at the same time, and discusses the worsening list.<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|486}} The chief mate informs the captain that the cars are floating in #3 cargo hold, and that the fire main is below the surface of the water, so he couldn't see the damage or if water was still coming in.<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|487–488}}
At 7:19 am, after further discussion with the chief mate, the captain calls the chief engineer again, asking, "Can you... isolate the fire main from down in the uh engine room?... On the engine room side the isolation valve [on the] suction [for the] fire pump... secure it, isolate it on your side so there's no free communication from the sea."<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|489–490}}
At 7:24 am, the captain, speaking with a crew member on the phone, says, "We still got reserve buoyancy and stability."<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|493}}
At 7:27 am, the captain instructs the second mate to ring the general alarm and wake up the crew.<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|493}}
At 7:29 am, the captain gives the order to abandon ship, and about a minute later can be heard on the bridge calling out, "Bow is down, bow is down."<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|499–500}}
At 7:31 am, the captain yells over the UHF radio for the chief mate to "Get into your rafts! Throw all your rafts into the water! Everybody get off! Get off the ship! Stay together!"<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|501}}
From 7:32 am on, the captain is heard trying to help the panicked [[helmsman]], an [[Able seaman|able seaman]], get off the bridge, with alarms ringing throughout.<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|502}} The captain repeatedly tells the helmsman not to panic: "work your way up here,"<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|504}} "you're okay, come on,"<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|505}} and "I'm not leavin' you, let's go!"<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|507}} The helmsman exclaims, "I need a ladder! A line!"<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|506}} and, "I need someone to help me!"<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|507}}
At 7:39 am, the VDR recording ends with the captain and AB still on the bridge.<ref name=vdr/>{{rp|509}}
===Search operations=== [[File:US Coast Guard searching for El Faro October 2015.jpg|left|thumb|150px|Conditions during the search for the ''El Faro'' on October 2 as seen from a Coast Guard HC-130]] On October 1, [[Hurricane Hunters]] WC-130J Super Hercules aircraft of the U.S. Air Force Reserve 53rd Weather Reconnaissance Squadron tried to locate ''El Faro'' without success.<ref>{{cite news|title=Coast Guard searching for missing cargo ship out of Jacksonville|date=October 2, 2015|work=[[WJAX-TV]]|publisher=[[Cox Media Group]]|accessdate=October 8, 2015|url=http://www.actionnewsjax.com/news/news/local/coast-guard-searching-missing-cargo-ship-out-jacks/nnskx/|location=Jacksonville, Florida}}</ref> On October 2, a Coast Guard [[Lockheed HC-130|HC-130H Hercules]] aircraft from CGAS Clearwater, Florida began a dedicated search for the ship.<ref name="USCG1">{{cite web|publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]]|date=October 2, 2015|accessdate=October 8, 2015|title=Coast Guard Searching for Container Ship Caught in Hurricane Joaquin|url=http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2606966/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151004222952/http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2606966|dead-url=yes|archive-date=October 4, 2015|location=Miami, Florida}}</ref> The [[USCGC Northland (WMEC-904)|USCGC ''Northland'']] and a [[Sikorsky MH-60 Jayhawk|MH-60T Jayhawk]] helicopter from CGAS Clearwater, Florida joined search efforts later that day.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]]|date=October 2, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=Update: Coast Guard searching for missing container ship caught in Hurricane Joaquin|url=http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2607214/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005233000/http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2607214|dead-url=yes|archive-date=October 5, 2015|location=Miami, Florida}}</ref> United States Coast Guard MH-65C Dolphin Helicopters from CGAS Miami, Florida and CGAS Borinquen, Puerto Rico along with HC-144A Ocean Sentry Fixed Wing Patrol Aircraft from Miami were also present. Aircraft on October 3 flew in violent hurricane conditions, characterized by winds in excess of {{convert|100|kn|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} at an altitude of {{convert|1000|ft|m|abbr=on}}, waves up to {{convert|40|ft|m|abbr=on}}, and visibility less than {{convert|1|nmi|abbr=on}}. Despite the hazardous conditions, a helicopter crew recovered a life ring from the vessel on this day.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]]|date=October 3, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=Update 2: Coast Guard Searching for Container Ship Caught in Hurricane Joaquin|url=http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2607366/|location=Miami, Florida|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151008004533/http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2607366/|archive-date=October 8, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Conditions markedly improved on October 4 as Joaquin moved northeast away from the Bahamas; winds averaged {{convert|15|kn|abbr=on}} and visibility was unlimited.<ref name="USCG4"/> Taking advantage of the clear weather, the helicopter remained in flight for 11 hours, requiring refueling twice.<ref name="NYTOct7"/> A second HC-130, the [[USCGC Charles Sexton (WPC-1108)|USCGC ''Charles Sexton'']], and the [[USCGC Resolute (WMEC-620)|USCGC ''Resolute'']] were deployed that day.<ref name="USCG4">{{cite web|publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]]|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=Update 4: Coast Guard Searching for Container Ship Caught in Hurricane Joaquin|url=http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2607474/|location=Miami, Florida|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151008021425/http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2607474/|archive-date=October 8, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> ''Northland'' and ''Resolute'' continued operations overnight with engineers using night vision goggles to take part in the search.<ref name="NYTOct7">{{cite news|author=Frances Robles|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|date=October 7, 2015|accessdate=October 8, 2015|title=Coast Guard to Suspend Search for Survivors of El Faro|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/08/us/coast-guard-to-suspend-search-for-survivors-of-el-faro.html|location=Jacksonville, Florida}}</ref><ref name="United States Coast Guard">{{cite web|publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]]|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=Update 5: Coast Guard Searching for Container Ship Caught in Hurricane Joaquin|url=http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2607510/|location=Miami, Florida|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151007195725/http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2607510|archive-date=October 7, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The [[United States Navy]] provided [[Boeing P-8 Poseidon|P-8A Poseidon fixed wing]] aircraft from NAS. Jacksonville, Florida to assist on October 5; three [[Crowley Maritime]] [[tugboat]]s also joined.<ref name="United States Coast Guard"/><ref name="USCGfinal"/> Search operations were conducted at a near-continuous pace by this date.<ref name="NYTOct7"/>
On October 5, an unidentified body in a [[survival suit]], presumed to be from ''El Faro'', was found but was not recovered. According to the rescue diver, the body was unrecognizable, its head three times normal size<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/01/books/review/into-raging-sea-rachel-slade.html|title=A Disaster at Sea, Animated by 26 Hours of Black-Box Recordings|date=2018-05-01|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-04|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>, and was left to be retrieved later in the day. However, a failure in the positioning device [[SLDMB]] ultimately resulted in losing the body.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dms.ntsb.gov/public/58000-58499/58116/598417.pdf |title=NTSB interview with USCG rescue diver |last= |first= |date= |website=dms.ntsb.gov |publisher= |access-date= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220124652/http://dms.ntsb.gov/public/58000-58499/58116/598417.pdf |archivedate=December 20, 2016 |df= }}</ref><ref name="BGOct5"/> Several other unopened suits were recovered.<ref name="WJXTOct10"/> A deflated life raft and a heavily damaged [[Lifeboat (shipboard)|lifeboat]]—one of two aboard ''El Faro'', each capable of carrying 43 people and stocked with food and water for a few days—with no one aboard were also found.<ref name="NYTOct7"/><ref name="BGOct5">{{cite news|author1=Jason Dearen |author2=Jennifer Kay |lastauthoramp=yes |agency=[[Associated Press]]|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|publisher=[[John W. Henry]]|date=October 5, 2015|accessdate=October 8, 2015|title=One body found, empty lifeboat located in search for crew of El Faro|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2015/10/05/one-body-found-empty-lifeboat-located-search-for-crew-faro/oZyLZu9G2bniFQ8BTQNCqI/story.html|location=Jacksonville, Florida}}</ref> The vessel was declared lost at sea on this day, believed to have sunk in {{convert|15,000|ft|m|abbr=on}} of water, and the search turned into a search-and-recovery effort.<ref name=NYT151005>{{cite news|author1=Lizette Alvarez |author2=Richard Péréz-Peña |author3=Frances Robles |last-author-amp=yes |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|date=October 5, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=U.S.-Based Cargo Ship With Crew of 33 Sank in Storm|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/06/us/el-faro-missing-ship-hurricane-joaquin.html|location=Miami, Florida}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=Erik Ortiz |author2=Elisha Fieldstadt |author3=Tom Winter |last-author-amp=yes |work=[[NBC News]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=October 5, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=El Faro, Cargo Ship Carrying 28 Americans, Believed to Have Sunk|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/el-faro-cargo-ship-carrying-28-americans-believed-have-sunk-n438466}}</ref> The [[United States Air Force]] and [[Air National Guard]] provided three additional HC-130P/J aircraft on October 6.<ref name="USCGfinal"/><ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]]|date=October 6, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=Update 9: Coast Guard Searching for Container Ship Caught in Hurricane Joaquin|url=http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2608222/|location=Miami, Florida|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151009224112/http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2608222|archive-date=October 9, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> A total of {{convert|183,000|nmi2|abbr=on}} of water was covered in search of the vessel.<ref name="USCGfinal">{{cite web|publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]]|date=October 7, 2015|accessdate=October 8, 2015|title=Coast Guard to suspend search for El Faro crew after 7-day search|url=http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2608214/|location=Miami, Florida|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151011013938/http://www.uscgnews.com/go/doc/4007/2608214|archive-date=October 11, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Two debris fields were discovered: one covering {{convert|260|nmi2|km2|abbr=on}} situated near ''El Faro''{{'}}s final position, and the other spanning {{convert|61|nmi2|km2|abbr=on}} located {{convert|60|nmi|km|abbr=on}} northeast of the first debris field. At sunset on October 7, the Coast Guard announced the cessation of search operations.<ref name="USCGfinal"/><ref name="CNNOct7">{{cite news|author1=Mariano Castillo |author2=Holly Yan |author3=Eliott C. McLaughlin |author4=Steve Almasy |last-author-amp=yes |work=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|date=October 7, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=El Faro search ends, Coast Guard says|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/10/07/us/el-faro-missing-ship/}}</ref>
==Aftermath== On October 7, a Navy salvage team was requested, at the behest of the [[National Transportation Safety Board]] (NTSB), to search for the wreckage.<ref name="CNNOct7"/> Florida Senator [[Bill Nelson (politician)|Bill Nelson]] wrote a letter to the NTSB urging them to look into TOTE's policies regarding severe weather.<ref name="WJXTOct10">{{cite press release|author=Calloway, Ethan |author2=Micolucci, Vic|publisher=[[WJXT]]/[[Graham Media Group]]|date=October 10, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=Sen. Bill Nelson meets with NTSB on ''El Faro'' investigation [link to Senator Nelson's letter to the NTSB dead]|url=http://www.news4jax.com/news/local/jacksonville/sen-bill-nelson-meets-with-ntsb-on-el-faro-investigation|format=PDF}}</ref> Nelson also cited that the vessel's lifeboats were "outdated and inadequate for the conditions the crew faced."<ref name="WJXTOct10"/> TOTE established a fund for families of the crew on October 9 through the [[Seamen's Church Institute of New York and New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Reiter, Emily|publisher=TOTE Maritime|website=elfaroincident.com|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=TOTE Establishes Family Relief Fund at Seamen’s Church|date=October 9, 2015|url=http://elfaroincident.com/el-faro-updates/tote-establishes-family-relief-fund-at-seamens-church-institute/|location=Jacksonville, Florida}}</ref> On October 14, a $100 million lawsuit was filed against TOTE by a family member of one of the missing crew, citing negligence on the company's behalf in letting a non-seaworthy vessel sail into a hurricane.<ref>{{cite news|author=Carrero, Jacquellena |work=[[NBC News]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=October 14, 2015|accessdate=October 18, 2015|title=Family of El Faro Crew Member Files $100M Lawsuit|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/family-el-faro-crew-member-files-100m-lawsuit-n444606}}</ref> On October 28, another lawsuit was filed on behalf of the estate of a man who died in the sinking. The complaint stated that “without power, the M/V EL FARO was merely a cork in the sea as the Hurricane neared.”<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.offshoreinjuryfirm.com/offshore-injury-blog/2015/october/arnold-itkin-llp-files-lawsuit-for-el-faro-sinki/ |title=Arnold & Itkin LLP Files Lawsuit for El Faro Sinking |author=Arnold & Itkin LLP |website=offshoreinjuryfirm.com||date=October 29, 2015 }}</ref> By April 19, 2016, TOTE Maritime had [[Settlement (litigation)|settled]] with 18 of the 33 families for more than $7 million.<ref>{{cite news|author=Kitchen, Sebastian |newspaper=The Florida Times-Union|date=March 2, 2016|accessdate=April 28, 2016|title=More families of El Faro crew members settle legal claims with ship's operator, owner|url=http://jacksonville.com/news/florida/2016-03-02/story/more-families-el-faro-crew-members-settle-legal-claims-ships-operator}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|work=WJXT|publisher=Graham Media Group|date=April 19, 2016|accessdate=April 28, 2016|title=18 El Faro families have settled with TOTE|url=http://www.news4jax.com/news/local/jacksonville/4-more-el-faro-families-settle-with-tote_|location=Jacksonville, Florida}}</ref>
The [[MV Isla Bella|MV ''Isla Bella'']] was chosen to replace ''El Faro''{{'}}s former operations.<ref>{{cite news|author=Readout, Stacey |work=WJXT|publisher=Graham Media Group|date=October 19, 2015|accessdate=October 19, 2015|title=Coast Guard certifies El Faro's replacement|url=http://www.news4jax.com/news/coast-guard-certifies-el-faros-replacement/35926164|location=Jacksonville, Florida}}</ref>
===Search for the wreckage=== [[File:CURV photo of the stern of El Faro 160103-N-ZZ999-550.jpg|thumb|A Navy screen capture showing the stern of ''El Faro''.]] On October 19, the [[USNS Apache (T-ATF-172)|USNS ''Apache'']] departed from [[Joint Expeditionary Base Little Creek–Fort Story]] in [[Virginia Beach, Virginia]] to conduct the underwater search for ''El Faro''. The vessel was equipped with a [[towed pinger locator]], [[side-scan sonar]], and a remotely operated vehicle.<ref name="CBS Corporation"/> The search crew identified a vessel on October 31 at an approximate depth of {{convert|15,000|ft|m|abbr=on}}. The hydrostatic pressure at this depth is approximately {{convert|6688|psi|kPa}}. The NTSB reported that the object was, "consistent with a [{{convert|790|ft|m|abbr=on}}] cargo ship...in an upright position and in one piece."<ref name="Steve Almasy"/> On November 16, the [[National Transportation Safety Board]] announced it had completed its search of the sunken ship but did not find the [[voyage data recorder]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/news/press-releases/Pages/PR_20151116.aspx|title= NTSB Completes Documentation of Sunken Cargo Ship ''EL FARO''; Voyage Data Recorder Not Located|website=National Transportation Safety Board|date=November 16, 2015|accessdate=November 16, 2015}}</ref> On January 3, 2016, the NTSB opened the public accident docket on the investigation into sinking of ''El Faro'', initially releasing underwater images and video of the vessel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/news/press-releases/Pages/PR01032016.aspx|title= NTSB Opens Public Docket on Investigation Into Cargo Ship Sinking; Underwater Images and Video Released|website=National Transportation Safety Board|date=January 3, 2016|accessdate=January 5, 2016}}</ref>
====Second and third search effort for VDR====
On April 18, 2016, the NTSB, utilizing the [[RV Atlantis (AGOR-25)|RV ''Atlantis'']], a Navy-owned vessel operated by mariners of [[Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution]], launched a second search for the ship's voyage data recorder (VDR). On April 26, the NTSB stated the voyage data recorder was found about {{convert|41|mi|km|abbr=on}} northeast of [[Acklins and Crooked Islands]], Bahamas. The NTSB was unable to retrieve the recorder at that time because of its proximity to the mast and other obstructions. On August 5, 2016, [[USNS Apache|USNS ''Apache'']] went back to the site. On August 9, 2016, the voyage data recorder was finally recovered from the wreckage by [[USNS Apache|USNS ''Apache'']], 10 months after the sinking. The VDR was then delivered to the NTSB in [[Mayport, FL]] to continue the investigation.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/u-recovers-data-recorder-sunken-cargo-ship-el-165252731.html?nhp=1 |title=U.S. recovers data recorder from sunken cargo ship ''El Faro''|work=Yahoo! News |publisher=Reuters |access-date=August 10, 2016}}</ref>
===Presentation of findings=== ====US Coast Guard==== The Coast Guard ''El Faro'' Marine Board of Investigation completed its final report on September 24, 2017 and published it on October 1, 2017 in its document library.<ref>{{cite web|website=US Coast Guard News-By-Region|url=http://www.news.uscg.mil/News-by-Region/Headquarters/El-Faro-Marine-Board-of-Investigation/ |author=U.S. Coast Guard ''El Faro'' Marine Board of Investigation|title= Document Library}}</ref> The 199-page Marine Board's Report detailed facts, analysis, and conclusions and made safety, administrative, and enforcement recommendations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://media.defense.gov/2017/Oct/01/2001820187/-1/-1/0/FINAL%20PDF%20ROI%2024%20SEP%2017.PDF |website=Department of Defense |author=U.S. Coast Guard ''El Faro'' Marine Board of Investigation|title= Final Report |date=September 24, 2017 |format=PDF |access-date=April 13, 2018}}</ref>
Coast Guard investigators placed nearly all of the blame on Michael Davidson, ''El Faro''{{'}}s captain. Davidson underestimated the strength of the storm and the ship's ability to ride it out, and did not take enough measures to evade the storm, even though his crew raised concerns about its increasing strength and changing direction. Investigators stated that if Davidson had survived the storm, his actions would have been grounds for the Coast Guard to revoke his captain's license. "(Davidson) was ultimately responsible for the vessel, the crew and its safe navigation," said Capt. Jason Neubauer, who chaired the investigation.
Coast Guard investigators also lambasted [[TOTE Maritime]],'' El Faro''{{'}}s owner, stating the company made several violations regarding crew members' rest periods and work hours, had no dedicated safety officer to oversee the ''El Faro'', and used outdated, "open air" lifeboats (similar to the types used on older vessels, such as the RMS ''Titanic'') instead of the modern-day enclosed survival crafts, among other violations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fox10tv.com/story/36494132/coast-guard-report-captain-errors-led-up-to-el-faro-sinking|title=Coast Guard report: Captain errors led up to ''El Faro'' sinking|work=Fox10 TV|access-date=October 15, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171015201752/http://www.fox10tv.com/story/36494132/coast-guard-report-captain-errors-led-up-to-el-faro-sinking|archive-date=October 15, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
====NTSB==== [[File:EL FARO Board Meeting (38972122842).jpg|thumb|NTSB model of the ''ElFaro'' wreck's resting place on the seafloor]] The NTSB met in Washington, D.C. on December 12, 2017, to discuss contributing factors to the sinking as well as to "vote on recommendations to address safety issues uncovered during the investigation."<ref name=ntsbbc>{{cite press release |author=National Transportation Safety Board |title=Meeting at NTSB Boardroom and Conference Center, December 12, 2017, to Discuss the October 2015 Sinking of the Cargo Ship ''El Faro'' in the Atlantic Ocean |url=https://www.ntsb.gov/news/events/Pages/2017-DCA16MM001-BMG.aspx |location=[[Washington, D.C.]] |publisher=NTSB.gov |agency= |date=September 12, 2017 |access-date=September 12, 2017}}</ref> The board meeting was webcast live.<ref name=ntsbbc/> The board's 400-page report: <ref name="NPR">{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/12/12/570129286/ntsb-releases-findings-on-what-sank-the-doomed-ship-el-faro |title=NTSB releases Findings on What Sank the Doomed Ship ''El Faro'' |date=December 12, 2017 |work=The Two Way|publisher=[[National Public Radio]] |accessdate=December 13, 2017}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/DCA16MM01_preliminary_report.pdf |title=Preliminary incident report|author= National Transportation Safety Board|website=NTSB.gov}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://ntsb.capitolconnection.org/#|website=Capital Connection|author= National Transportation Safety Board|title=Presentation of Findings and Vote to Recommendations|date= December 12, 2017 }} (Archive of video from the NTSB meeting held December 12, 2017) </ref> * criticized the captain's decision to advance into the oncoming storm, despite numerous calls from the crew to alter course, and noted he had relied on outdated weather information from a commercial service *criticized the Coast Guard's practices of grandfathering in vessels, exempting them from using closed lifeboats: the obsolescent lifeboats were not properly maintained, they were not launched, and in all probability they would not have offered useful shelter *noted the owner's failure to maintain a superannuated and deteriorating vessel In their final report,the NTSB determines{{quote|''that the probable cause of the sinking of El Faro and the subsequent loss of life was the captain’s insufficient action to avoid Hurricane Joaquin, his failure to use the most current weather information, and his late decision to muster the crew. Contributing to the sinking was ineffective bridge resource management on board El Faro, which included the captain’s failure to adequately consider officers’ suggestions. Also contributing to the sinking was the inadequacy of both TOTE’s oversight and its safety management system. Further contributing factors (...) were flooding in a cargo hold from an undetected open watertight scuttle and damaged seawater piping; loss of propulsion due to low lube oil pressure to the main engine resulting from a sustained list; and subsequent downflooding through unsecured ventilation closures to the cargo holds. Also contributing (...) was the lack of an approved damage control plan (...) Contributing to the loss of life was the lack of appropriate survival craft for the conditions''.<ref>[https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/DCA16MM01_preliminary_report.pdf Marine Accident Report. Sinking of US Cargo Vessel SS El Faro. Atlantic Ocean, Northeast of Acklins and Crooked Island, Bahamas. October 1, 2015 (pdf)] National Transportation Safety Board</ref>}}
==See also== {{portal|2010s|Nautical|Disasters|Tropical cyclones}} *[[List of Bermuda Triangle incidents]] *[[List of disasters in the United States by death toll]] *[[List of maritime disasters in the 21st century]] *[[List of roll-on/roll-off vessel accidents]] *[[List of shipwrecks in 2015]] *[[List of shipwrecks of North America]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
== Further reading== * Foy, George Michelsen. ''Run the Storm: A Savage Hurricane, a Brave Crew, and the Wreck of the SS El Faro'' ([[Charles Scribner's Sons]], May 1, 2018) * Korten, Tristram. ''Into the Storm: Two Ships, a Deadly Hurricane, and an Epic Battle for Survival'' ([[Ballantine Books]], April 24, 2018) * Slade, Rachel. ''Into the Raging Sea: Thirty-Three Mariners, One Megastorm, and the Sinking of El Faro'' ([[Ecco Press]], May 1, 2018) * Frump, Robert. "The Captains of Thor -- What Really Caused the Loss of the SS El Faro" ({Race Point} September 27, 2018)

{{Infobox military person |name = '''Saliya Upul Aladeniya''' {{KIA}} |honorific_suffix=PWV |birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1963|3|1}} |death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1990|6|11|1963|3|1}} |birth_place = [[Lewella]], [[Kandy]] |death_place = [[Kokavil]], [[Sri Lanka]] |image = Captain Saliya Upul Aladeniya.jpg|150x |birth_name = Samarakoon Wasala Mudiyanselage Saliya Upul Aladeniya |caption = |nickname = |allegiance = {{flag|Sri Lanka}} |branch = {{army|Sri Lanka}} |serviceyears = 1989-1990 |rank = [[File:Sri Lanka-army-OF-2.svg|10px]] [[Captain (land and air)|Captain]] |commands = Officer-in-command, [[Kokavil]] Army Camp |unit = [[Sri Lanka Sinha Regiment]] |battles = [[Sri Lankan civil war]] |awards = [[File:Parama veera vibhushanaya.svg|23px]] [[Parama Weera Vibhushanaya]] |laterwork = }} [[Captain]] '''Samarakoon Wasala Mudiyanselage Saliya Upul Aladeniya''', [[Parama Weera Vibhushanaya|PWV]], [[Sri Lanka Sinha Regiment|SLRS]] (In [[Sinhalese language|Sinhalese]]: කපිතාන් සාලිය උපුල් අලදෙනිය; 1 March 1963 – 11 June 1990) was [[Sri Lanka]]n soldier and the second recipient of the [[Parama Weera Vibhushanaya]], highest war time award for valor of Sri Lanka. He was commanding the small army detachment at [[Kokavil]], when it was surrounded he refused to abandon the injured and fought until they were overrun by [[LTTE]].<ref>[http://sundaytimes.lk/001001/plus4.html The Sunday Times article: "Don't worry sir, I will fight till I die"]</ref><ref>[http://www.lankalibrary.com/phpBB/viewtopic.php?t=2399&/ LankaLibrary Forum; Eelam War II - "Operation Balavegaya"]</ref>
Born in [[Kandy]], his father was a [[Captain]] in the [[Ceylon Army Volunteer Force]]. Educated at [[Trinity College (Kandy)|Trinity College Kandy]], he joined the [[Sri Lanka Army]] in 1989 as a volunteer officer. Following a short commissioning course at the [[Sri Lanka Military Academy]], he was commissioned as [[Second Lieutenant]] into the 2nd(v) Battalion, [[Sri Lanka Sinha Regiment]] and served with it in [[Nuwara Eliya]].
In May, [[Lieutenant]] Aladeniya and his platoon was deployed to an isolated army outpost at Kokuvla (Kokavil) that was established for guarding the television [[Broadcast relay station|relay station]]. The camp was surrounded for several days by LTTE cadres who outnumbered them five to one. The food and water were running out in the camp and so was the [[ammunition]]. In spite of many requests, [[reinforcements]] sent from Wanni headquarters never reached Kokavil, having been diverted elsewhere. On July 11, orders to withdraw from the camp came at the eleventh hour but then it was too late and Aladeniya had wounded men whom he did not want to leave behind. Pledging that he would rather die alongside them than leave them, Lt. Aladeniya fought on till an adjacent [[fuel dump]] exploded, killing the majority of the defenders in the camp. Since his body was not recovered he has been listed as missing in action.
Aladeniya was posthumously promoted to rank of [[Captain (land and air)|Captain]] and awarded the [[Parama Weera Vibhushanaya]] medal on June 21, 1994. In offensive operations in 2009, the Sri Lanka Army recaptured Kokavil. In 2011, the transmition tower was rebuilt and a monument to Aladeniya and his men was built.<ref>[http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2011/06/12/fea02.asp Saved through blood, sweat and tears:]</ref>
==See also== *[[Awards and decorations of the military of Sri Lanka]]
==References== {{reflist}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060821030241/http://www.spur.asn.au/Curr5.htm SPUR] *Army, Sri Lanka. (1st Edition - October 1999). ''"50 YEARS ON" - 1949-1999'', [[Sri Lanka Army]]. {{ISBN|955-8089-02-8}}
